utterances: Can you provide me with more information about what courses are included in the curriculum for this program?
What is the curriculum for the program?
answers: Here is a general overview of the topics covered in the 2IS program: 1) Fundamentals of Internet Studies: Introduction to the internet, its history, evolution, and its role in society. 2) Legal and Ethical Aspects: Exploration of legal frameworks and regulations related to the internet, including privacy, intellectual property, cybercrime, and ethical considerations in the digital era. 3) Economics and Business: Analysis of the economic aspects of the internet, such as e-commerce, digital marketing, online business models, and the impact of the digital economy on traditional industries. 4) Digital Technologies: Examination of the technical aspects of the internet, including web development, programming languages, databases, networking, and emerging technologies. 5) Social and Cultural Impacts: Study of the social, cultural, and behavioral aspects of the internet, including the influence of social media, online communities, virtual reality, and the digital divide. 6) Digital Transformation and Innovation: Exploration of the strategies, challenges, and opportunities associated with digital transformation in organizations, as well as the role of innovation in the digital era. 7) Research Methods: Introduction to research methodologies and techniques used in the field of internet studies. It's important to note that the program structure, specific courses, and credit requirements may vary. I recommend visiting the official website of University Toulouse 1 Capitole or contacting the relevant department for detailed and updated information regarding the 2IS program curriculum.

The program includes subjects such as business intelligence, data analytics, project management and agility, programming using Java, software analysis and design, and the option to study either French or English as a foreign language. Additionally, the curriculum includes courses that focus on personal and professional development, research workshops, and term projects. In the second year, students have the opportunity to take a variety of elective courses, such as innovative software methods, innovative data management, cybersecurity, internet of things and web development, advanced artificial intelligence, sustainable information systems, and user interface and user experience design.

The curriculum for the program includes courses in business intelligence, data analytics, project management and agility, advanced programming in Java, software analysis and design, and foreign language (French or English). It also includes professionalization courses in soft skills and personal development, research workshops, and term projects. In the second year, students can choose from a range of courses in innovative software methods, innovative data management, cybersecurity, internet of things and web development, advanced topics in artificial intelligence, sustainable information systems, and user interface and user experience.

utterances: What are the goals of the program
Who is this program designed for
tell me about the goals of the program
answers: The 2IS Master program is designed for Bachelor students in information technologies (IT) aiming to expand their knowledge on innovative information technologies. 2IS is organised by researchers of IRIT (Institut de Recherche en Informatique de Toulouse), one of the major French institutes in computer science. 2IS is a MIAGE Master program (Méthodes Informatiques Appliquées à la Gestion des Entreprises), which is the reference Master in France for information technolgy. MIAGE programs are run by more than 20 universities in France. Innovative information technologies reinvent and transform businesses. Artificial intelligence, big data and web-service orchestration drastically impact end-users as automation is at the heart of business processes.

The 2IS Master program is tailored for IT Bachelor students who wish to enhance their understanding of cutting-edge information technologies. It is organized by IRIT (Institut de Recherche en Informatique de Toulouse), a leading French institute in computer science. 2IS is part of the MIAGE Master program (Méthodes Informatiques Appliquées à la Gestion des Entreprises), a widely recognized program in France for IT. MIAGE programs are offered by over 20 universities in France. Innovative information technologies play a critical role in shaping and transforming businesses, with areas such as artificial intelligence, big data and web-service orchestration having significant impact on end-users as automation becomes increasingly central to business processes.

The 2IS program offers a comprehensive and unique view of innovation in information technology over a 2-year period, covering topics such as innovative software solutions, software development methods, and innovation and entrepreneurship in strategy and management. These include business intelligence and data visualization, machine learning, collective intelligence, distributed databases, agile management, and collaborative design.

utterances: how much does it cost to live in toulouse
answers: Living costs in Toulouse are around 800€ per month, with accommodation costing around 300/400 euros per month for a room in a shared apartment or a small studio. Social security in France is free for all students (or subject to a small fee of around 100 euros per year). Consult our student guide for more detailed information.

Toulouse hosts more than 14.000 international students, and the University of Toulouse offers dedicated services to facilitate the your arrival -> Toul’Box : customisable packages that you can purchase before arrival, providing you with a bank account, health insurance, sim card... up to looking for an accommodation for you (price range 400-600 EUR per month). -> Welcome Desk : the first place to visit upon arrival, provides support to all prospective students, with a dedicated office for visa applications.  Here is a guide on student housing written by the international relations office of UT Capitole <https://www.ut-capitole.fr/campus/practical-information/accommodation-858871.kjsp?RH=1541674311657>. The first semester of the program, titled 'Fundamentals' covers a wide range of topics including business intelligence, data analytics, project management, advanced programming, software analysis and design, foreign language (either French or English), soft skills, personal development, research workshop 1, and term project 1. The second semester, 'Towards Innovation' includes courses in business process modeling, artificial intelligence, web services, marketing and entrepreneurship, foreign language, soft skills, personal development, research workshop 2, and an internship or term project 2. The third semester, 'Innovation in IT' delves into innovative data management, cybersecurity, internet of things and web development, advanced topics in artificial intelligence, sustainable information systems, user interface and user experience, strategy and innovation, foreign language, and research workshop 3. The final semester, 'Innovation in Action' is a 5-month internship in a company, followed by a final examination and is worth 20 ECTS.

The program is divided into four semesters, each with a specific focus. The first semester, 'Fundamentals' covers a variety of topics such as business intelligence, data analytics, and programming. The second semester, 'Towards Innovation' includes courses on business process modeling, artificial intelligence, and marketing. The third semester, 'Innovation in IT' focuses on topics such as innovative data management and cybersecurity. The final semester, 'Innovation in Action' is a 5-month internship with a final examination at the end, worth 20 ECTS.

And finally you will be working in Research Workshop and on a Term project, worthing each 2 ECTS.

In the second semester, you will be enrolled in four Towards Innovation courses, each carrying 5 ECTS credits. These courses include Business Process Modelling, Artificial Intelligence, Web Services, and Marketing and Entrepreneurship. Additionally, you will participate in Professionalisation courses aimed at enhancing your integration into the professional world, focusing on soft skills and personal development (4 ECTS). You will also have the opportunity to study a foreign language (French or English). Furthermore, you will engage in a Research Workshop (2 ECTS) and complete a Term project or undertake a 1-month internship (3 ECTS).

utterances: What is the syllabus of bi
answers: The objectives of this course are to understand the concepts related to Business Intelligence as well as to design and implement the components of a decision support system. First, we study the components and the role of decision support systems. Second, we learn how to design and deploy a data warehouse. Third, we address the multidimensional modeling of data marts. Finally, we discuss some state-of-the-art solutions dedicated to data visualization.

The primary goals of this course are to develop a comprehensive understanding of Business Intelligence concepts and acquire the skills to design and implement decision support systems. The course covers various aspects, starting with an examination of decision support system components and their significance. Next, students learn about data warehouse design and implementation. The course also delves into multidimensional modeling techniques for data marts. Finally, students explore cutting-edge solutions for data visualization that are specifically tailored to the field of Business Intelligence.

answers:
The software analysis code focuses on modelling software: it considers at first the structural and behavioral
perspectives for analysing user needs; in a second step it focuses on requirements
definition and finally overview classical patterns considered in the design stage. The class
goes through the main UML diagrams and emphasizes the object paradigm for analyzing
and designing a software system.

The software analysis centers around software modeling. It begins by examining the structural and behavioral aspects of analyzing user requirements. Then, it delves into requirements definition and provides an overview of classical patterns commonly used during the design phase. The course covers the essential Unified Modeling Language (UML) diagrams and emphasizes the object-oriented paradigm for analyzing and designing software systems.

Data analysis is crucial to help business and decision-making. Data analytics encompasses descriptive and predictive analysis. This course aims at giving the students the keys to understand data analytics and associated concepts. In this course, we present both descriptive and predictive analysis as well as related topics that computer scientists should consider when analyzing data: data representation, data visualization and result interpretation. The main supervised and unsupervised machine learning methods are introduced as well as the contexts of applications. This course does not aim at going deep in the mathematical formulation of the methods.

Data analysis plays a vital role in business and decision-making processes. It involves descriptive and predictive analysis. The purpose of this course is to provide students with the necessary knowledge to comprehend data analytics and its associated concepts. The course covers descriptive and predictive analysis, along with important considerations for computer scientists when analyzing data, such as data representation, data visualization, and result interpretation. The course introduces key supervised and unsupervised machine learning methods and explores their application contexts. It should be noted that the course does not delve deeply into the mathematical formulation of these methods.

utterances: will we also learn project management?
answers:
The objective of this course is to introduce the fundamental concepts of project management, with
particular attention to information system projects.
As announced, this course is structured in two parts.
A first part dedicated to traditional Project Management Methods, because it is important to
understand the basics of traditional Project Management in order to appreciate the benefits of
adopting innovative techniques. Traditional Project Management methods are based on deterministic
approaches that use detailed plans, Gantt charts, work schedules….
A second part dedicated to Agile methods. Such methods promote a value-driven approach that
allows the Project Manager to deliver high-priority, high-quality work. It is based on iterative and
incremental development in which requirements and solutions evolve through collaboration.

The aim of this course is to provide an introduction to the fundamental concepts of project management, with a specific focus on information system projects. The course is divided into two parts.

The first part covers traditional project management methods. It is important to understand these traditional methods in order to appreciate the benefits of adopting innovative techniques. Traditional project management approaches rely on deterministic strategies that involve detailed plans, Gantt charts, and work schedules.

The second part of the course is dedicated to Agile methods. Agile methods promote a value-driven approach that enables project managers to deliver high-priority, high-quality work. These methods are based on iterative and incremental development, where requirements and solutions evolve through collaboration.

Lectures are be organised around three activities:
1.Webpage and discussion platform (Activity 1): students have to create a webpage of
the course, containing the minutes of each class, the program of past and future lectures,
as well as a sharing or discussion forum where ideas for individual and group presentation
are discussed and voted, as well as a suitable platform to share and present the material
created in class.
2.Group presentations (Activity 2): each week the teacher together with the students
selects a group of 3 or 4 students and a topic for next week’s lecture, choosing among
those discussed on the webpage. The group is then responsible to prepare a 30 minutes
presentation on the chosen topic.
3.Individual presentations (Activity 3): topics can be proposed by single students on the
discussion platform and can be voted by the other students. Once a month the most voted
proposal is selected and a 30 minutes individual presentation is prepared by the student
behind the proposal.

As the trends evolve towards automation and artificial intelligence, and as many technical
skills could become obsolete in the coming years, companies are showing an increasing
interest in skills that cannot be delegated to a robot: Soft skills, or behavioral skills, are the
most sought-after skills by recruiters, in addition to technical know-how. If creativity,
interpersonal skills and team spirit have always been part of the marketing and
communication professional's panoply, the soft skills expected by the sector are evolving
towards emotional intelligence (empathy, listening) to understand others, efficiency and
organization in the face of the speed inherent in business, boldness and an entrepreneurial
spirit oriented towards the search for solutions, the ability to create meaning in daily
professional life, curiosity and openness to allow one's own skills to evolve and to learn to
learn during one's career.

As automation and artificial intelligence continue to advance, there is a growing recognition among companies that certain skills cannot be easily replaced by technology. These skills, known as soft skills or behavioral skills, are highly valued by recruiters alongside technical expertise. While creativity, interpersonal skills, and teamwork have always been important in marketing and communication professions, the specific soft skills sought after in the industry are evolving.

The evolving soft skills in the field now include emotional intelligence, such as empathy and active listening, which enable professionals to understand others. Efficiency and organizational abilities are also crucial in fast-paced business environments. Additionally, a bold and entrepreneurial mindset focused on finding solutions is highly valued. Professionals are expected to create meaning in their daily work, demonstrate curiosity and openness to continuously evolve their skills, and develop a lifelong learning approach throughout their careers.

What is business process modelling about
answers:
Business Processes (BPs) are widely recognized as an essential component of Information
Systems given the growing need for organizations to both cooperate with others and
coordinate their activities inside their own structure.
This course will cover the BP life-cycle including process design, its enactment as a workflow
and also process discovering and analysis. Both theoretical backgrounds and tools will be
presented to allow students to build Process Aware Information Systems.

Business Processes (BPs) are increasingly acknowledged as a crucial element of Information Systems, as organizations strive to collaborate with external parties and streamline their internal operations. This course provides a comprehensive understanding of the BP life cycle, encompassing process design, workflow enactment, and process discovery and analysis. The course presents theoretical foundations and tools that empower students to construct Process Aware Information Systems.

Web services are now a mature technology to organize an Information System and make
available the content of a database with a given API, allowing users to build their own
application on top of this data. This course objective is to let student build a project where
they can build an application able to consume external web services (thus access data from
external web services), and build a webservice to provide new data.

Web services have evolved into a well-established technology for organizing an Information System and providing access to database content through a defined API. They enable users to develop their own applications utilizing this data. The objective of this course is to enable students to create a project where they can construct an application capable of consuming external web services, thereby accessing data from these external sources. Additionally, students will learn how to develop a web service that offers new data, allowing other applications to utilize this information. The course provides practical hands-on experience in working with web services, emphasizing both consuming and providing data through this technology. Students will gain insights into the implementation and integration of web services within an Information System.

This course trains students to marketing and innovation/entrepreneurship approaches and
methods. Students will be able to conceive and develop marketing strategies and tools
(SWOT, PORTER analysis, Boston box…). Teaching methods used in this program include
theory, case studies, practitioner conferences and a real company project. Students will
take part in an innovation journey and build the most relevant and innovative concept on an
exclusive topic given by an industrial group. Students will pitch their idea in front of a jury of
managers and representatives.
At the end of the lectures students will also understand major issues and methods
regarding entrepreneurship such as: acknowledge start up specificities, describe Business
Model Canevas, understand what innovation is. This course also trains students to ideation
techniques and creativity management. This course puts the emphasis on a good
complementarity between academic and practical insights.
This course stresses on basic marketing for innovation technics and tools. Our lessons are
divided in three majors parts (introduction to marketing, strategical part and operational
part). We are using theory and real examples of companies or brands. Furthermore,
students apply their knowledge to concrete business situations.

This course is designed to provide students with training in marketing, innovation, and entrepreneurship. It equips students with the skills and methods necessary to conceive and develop effective marketing strategies and tools, such as SWOT analysis, PORTER analysis, and the Boston Box. The teaching methods employed in this program include theoretical instruction, case studies, practitioner conferences, and engagement in a real company project.

Students will embark on an innovation journey, where they will work on developing the most relevant and innovative concept within a specific topic provided by an industrial group. They will have the opportunity to pitch their ideas in front of a jury composed of managers and representatives.

Throughout the course, students will also gain a comprehensive understanding of major issues and methods related to entrepreneurship, including an understanding of start-up specificities, familiarity with the Business Model Canvas, and a grasp of the concept of innovation. Ideation techniques and creativity management will be emphasized, promoting a balance between academic knowledge and practical insights.

The course places significant emphasis on basic marketing techniques and tools for innovation. The lessons are divided into three main parts: an introduction to marketing, a strategic component, and an operational segment. Theory is combined with real-world examples from companies and brands, allowing students to apply their knowledge to concrete business situations.

The course is structured in two parts.
1. Machine learning: building on the “Data Analytics” course proposed in the first
semester, students will learn the basics of supervised machine learning such as
SVM, linear classifiers, deep learning, and bayesian inference. At the same time,
students will be asked to complete a group project in 5 weeks, selecting one of the
techniques presented during the course and implementing it (typical example: a
classification problem).
2. Reasoning: the second part of the course will cover classical AI techniques such as
exploration and search algorithms, game playing, and constraint satisfaction. A set
of exercises to be solved individually on paper will be proposed, as well as a
second project based on modeling and solving a constraint satisfaction problem,
with the objective of winning the end-of-course tournament.
Each part of the course lasts for 6 weeks, with the first 2 weeks dedicated to lectures by
the teachers, and the remaining weeks consisting of tutoring sessions in the lab and
student presentations. These two aspects are completed with an introductory session on
AI in the form of a world coffee and two lectures on the history and ethics in AI.

The course is divided into two main parts.

In the first part, which builds upon the "Data Analytics" course offered in the previous semester, students will delve into the fundamentals of supervised machine learning. They will explore topics such as support vector machines (SVM), linear classifiers, deep learning, and Bayesian inference. Additionally, during this phase, students will engage in a group project that spans five weeks. They will have the opportunity to select one of the techniques covered in the course and implement it practically, typically in the context of a classification problem.

The second part of the course focuses on reasoning and covers classical artificial intelligence (AI) techniques. Students will delve into exploration and search algorithms, game playing strategies, and constraint satisfaction. They will be presented with a series of individual exercises to solve on paper, and a second project will be assigned centered around modeling and solving a constraint satisfaction problem. The ultimate objective of this part is for students to participate in an end-of-course tournament and demonstrate their ability to tackle and solve complex AI problems.

Each part of the course spans six weeks, with the first two weeks dedicated to lectures delivered by the instructors. The subsequent weeks involve tutoring sessions in the laboratory and student presentations. Additionally, the course includes an introductory session on AI, designed as a world coffee event, and two lectures that delve into the history and ethics of AI.

utterances: What is Innovative Data Management about
There is a course Called IDM please explain it
answers:
Considering the large volume and the variety of data that companies have to manage and analyze,
this course reviews the different architectures proposed by database manufacturers to take
advantage of parallelism and to ensure reliability as well as scalability. Indexing strategies for
optimizing data retrieval are also reviewed.
Many lab sessions allow students to get know-how on the Cloudera CDH distribution, Oracle and
SQL Server. A week-long project concludes this course.

In light of the extensive amount and diverse nature of data that organizations need to handle and analyze, this course examines various architectures proposed by database vendors to leverage parallelism and ensure reliability and scalability. It also covers indexing strategies to optimize data retrieval. The course includes several laboratory sessions to provide students with practical experience using Cloudera CDH distribution, Oracle, and SQL Server. A week-long project serves as the culmination of the course.

Corporations (large, medium and small-sized) play a central role in the economic activity of
most developed countries. To survive and outperform their rivals, corporations must acquire
and sustain competitive advantage mainly through innovation in terms of products, process,
organization and/or business models.
The course is meant to introduce students to the world of corporate, business, operational
strategies and innovation management. The main objective is to provide an overview of the
basics of strategy and innovation as well as the most prevalent concepts, methods and
tools for thinking about and managing technology businesses.
Theoretical underpinnings taught in the course include models of industry analysis,
strategic diagnosis and positioning, strategy formulation and implementation. The course
will also consider the internal structure, processes, resources and core competencies with
which a firm is endowed, including lectures, cases discussion and exercises alternately

Corporations of all sizes, including large, medium, and small-sized companies, play a crucial role in the economies of developed countries. To thrive and surpass their competitors, corporations need to continuously innovate in terms of products, processes, organization, and business models to establish and maintain a competitive advantage.

This course aims to introduce students to the field of corporate, business, operational strategies, and innovation management. Its primary objective is to provide an overview of the fundamentals of strategy and innovation, along with the key concepts, methods, and tools for managing technology-based businesses.

The course covers theoretical foundations such as models for industry analysis, strategic diagnosis and positioning, and strategy formulation and implementation. Additionally, it explores the internal structure, processes, resources, and core competencies that shape a firm, employing a combination of lectures, case discussions, and practical exercises.

utterances: Internet of things and web development
What is Internet of things and web development about
answers:
The goal of this course is two-fold: first, study foundations of server-side scripting and
second study internet of things. To do so, we consider an end-to-end perspective: starting
from sensors and actuators, next information diffusion, next information storing and finally
visualization with web-based applications.

This course has a dual objective. Firstly, it aims to explore the foundations of server-side scripting, focusing on the development of dynamic web applications. Secondly, it delves into the concept of the Internet of Things (IoT). The course takes an end-to-end approach, covering various aspects from the initial stage of sensor and actuator integration, to the transmission of information, storage of data, and ultimately the visualization of the collected data using web-based applications. By studying these topics, students will gain a comprehensive understanding of both server-side scripting and the IoT, enabling them to develop practical solutions and applications in this domain.",

utterances: What is Advanced Topics in Artificial Intelligence about
answers:
The purpose of this course is to give students in-depth knowledge in three advanced areas of
artificial intelligence: complete the training in learning techniques with the use of deep learning
architectures (part 1), provide students with the tools to set up a multi-agent simulation from
modelling, data integration to the final analysis (part 2), model the rational behaviour of autonomous
agents and analyse the algorithmic properties of socio-economic applications (part 3).
The course is structured in three parts which will be taught in sequence:
1. Deep learning. This part will first detail the functioning of artificial neural networks and inner
mechanisms used to optimize synaptic weights. Practical sessions will be given in order to build
deep neural networks to image analysis and to natural language processing. The framework Keras
in Python will be used in this class.
2. Multiagent Simulations. We will introduce the modelling and simulation of complex systems (social
systems in particular) using multi-agent simulation and will detail the main steps of this process, from
data analysis, agent-based modelling, programing on a simulation platform (Netlogo or Gama),
simulation exploration (using Open-mole) to the analysis of the results. The course will
alternate theoretical approaches and practical issues.
3. Rational decisions and social algorithms. We will introduce the main algorithms used in
socio-economic activities, with a strong accent on those studied in the area of multiagent systems.
The theoretical and practical aspects of these algorithms and mathematical models will be analysed.
Topics varies each year and can include: introduction to game theory (strategic,
extensive, repeated), auction and mechanism design, online advertising markets, matching
mechanisms, human computation and crowdsourcing, social choice and voting, reputation systems,
social network analysis and diffusion on networks, and digital currencies.

The objective of this course is to provide students with comprehensive knowledge in three advanced areas of artificial intelligence. The course is divided into three parts, each focusing on a specific topic:

Deep Learning: This part explores the principles and mechanisms of artificial neural networks, with a specific emphasis on deep learning architectures. Students will gain an understanding of how to optimize synaptic weights and apply deep neural networks to image analysis and natural language processing. Practical sessions will involve using the Python-based framework Keras.

Multiagent Simulations: This part introduces the modeling and simulation of complex systems, particularly social systems, using multi-agent simulation techniques. Students will learn the key steps involved in this process, including data analysis, agent-based modeling, programming simulations on platforms like Netlogo or Gama, conducting simulation explorations using Open-mole, and analyzing the results. The course will incorporate both theoretical approaches and practical exercises.

Rational Decisions and Social Algorithms: This part focuses on the study of algorithms used in socio-economic activities, with an emphasis on those applied in multi-agent systems. Students will explore the theoretical and practical aspects of these algorithms and mathematical models. The topics covered may vary each year and can include game theory, auction and mechanism design, online advertising markets, matching mechanisms, human computation and crowdsourcing, social choice and voting, reputation systems, social network analysis, diffusion on networks, and digital currencies.

By covering these advanced topics, the course aims to equip students with a deep understanding of learning techniques, multi-agent simulations, and rational decision-making in socio-economic contexts within the field of artificial intelligence.

Lectures will be organised around three activities:
1. Reading, understanding, and presenting scientific papers (Activity 1): each student
will pick one article from a set proposed by a teacher, and prepares a short presentation
(15-20 minutes) to explain it to the group, contextualising it to a particular problem.
2. Interview with researchers (Activity 2): each student selects a researcher in Toulouse
who works in the topic of the scientific paper chosen, and interview her/him on the latest
finding in her/his field, her/his motivation to become a researcher, and her/his connections
to industry.
3. Conceiving and writing a group position paper (Activity 2): four groups of students will
research on four topics (privacy, job market, inequalities, warfare), producing each a
position paper and a final presentation suggesting policies to tackle the social
consequences of innovation in IT.
4. Individual presentations (Activity 3): topics can be proposed by single students on the
discussion platform and can be voted by the other students. Once a month the most voted
proposal is selected and a 30 minutes individual presentation is prepared by the student
behind the proposal.

At the University of Toulouse Capitole's Faculty of Information Technologies, we emphasize innovative approaches to teaching. utterances: What are the credits for each course?
answers: In semester 1, the course 'Business intelligence' is worth 4 ECTS, 'Data analytics' is worth 4 ECTS, 'Project management and agility' is worth 5 ECTS, 'Advanced programming in Java' is worth 4 ECTS, 'Software analysis and design' is worth 4 ECTS, 'Foreing language (French or English)' is worth 6 ECTS, 'Soft skills and personal development' is worth 4 ECTS, 'Research workshop 1' is worth 2 ECTS, and 'Term project 1' is worth 2 ECTS. In semester 2, the course 'Business process modeling' is worth 5 ECTS, 'Artificial intelligence' is worth 5 ECTS, 'Web services' is worth 5 ECTS, 'Marketing and entrepreneurship' is worth 5 ECTS, 'Foreing language (French or English)' is worth 6 ECTS, 'Soft skills and personal development' is worth 4 ECTS, 'Research workshop 2' is worth 2 ECTS, and 'Internship or term project 2' is worth 3 ECTS. In semester 3, the course 'Innovative data management' is worth 6 ECTS and includes a 'project week', 'Cybersecurity' is worth 2 ECTS, 'Internet of things and web development' is worth 6 ECTS and includes a 'project week', 'Advanced topics in artificial intelligence' is worth 6 ECTS and includes a 'project week', 'Sustainable information systems' is worth 2 ECTS, 'User interface and user experience' is worth 2 ECTS and includes a 'project week', 'Strategy and innovation' is worth 5 ECTS, 'Foreing language (French or English)' is worth 3 ECTS, and 'Research workshop 3' is worth 2 ECTS. In semester 4, students will complete a 5-month 'internship in a company' and take a 'final examination' worth 20 ECTS.

In the first semester, there are several courses with corresponding ECTS credits. The course 'Business intelligence' carries 4 ECTS, 'Data analytics' carries 4 ECTS, 'Project management and agility' carries 5 ECTS, 'Advanced programming in Java' carries 4 ECTS, 'Software analysis and design' carries 4 ECTS, 'Foreign language (French or English)' carries 6 ECTS, 'Soft skills and personal development' carries 4 ECTS, 'Research workshop 1' carries 2 ECTS, and 'Term project 1' carries 2 ECTS.

Moving on to the second semester, the course 'Business process modeling' carries 5 ECTS, 'Artificial intelligence' carries 5 ECTS, 'Web services' carries 5 ECTS, 'Marketing and entrepreneurship' carries 5 ECTS, 'Foreign language (French or English)' carries 6 ECTS, 'Soft skills and personal development' carries 4 ECTS, 'Research workshop 2' carries 2 ECTS, and students have the option to either undertake an internship or a term project worth 3 ECTS.

In the third semester, the course 'Innovative data management' carries 6 ECTS and includes a 'project week'. 'Cybersecurity' carries 2 ECTS, 'Internet of things and web development' carries 6 ECTS and includes a 'project week', 'Advanced topics in artificial intelligence' carries 6 ECTS and includes a 'project week', 'Sustainable information systems' carries 2 ECTS, 'User interface and user experience' carries 2 ECTS and includes a 'project week', 'Strategy and innovation' carries 5 ECTS, 'Foreign language (French or English)' carries 3 ECTS, and 'Research workshop 3' carries 2 ECTS.

Finally, in the fourth semester, students are required to complete a 5-month 'internship in a company' and take a 'final examination' worth 20 ECTS.

These courses and activities are designed to provide students with a comprehensive education in various aspects of information technologies, including technical skills, project management, soft skills, research, and real-world experience through internships.

utterances: What are the courses that we will take in the program?
answers: The program is divided into four semesters, each with its own focus and objectives. In the first semester, students will cover Fundamentals, taking courses such as Business Intelligence, Data Analytics, Project Management and Agility, Advanced Programming in Java, Software Analysis and Design, and a Foreign Language (French or English). They will also take Soft Skills and Personal Development, Research Workshop 1, and Term Project 1. In the second semester, students will move on to Towards Innovation, taking courses such as Business Process Modeling, Artificial Intelligence, Web Services, Marketing and Entrepreneurship, and a Foreign Language. They will also take Soft Skills and Personal Development, Research Workshop 2, and have the option to choose between an Internship or Term Project 2. In the third semester, students will focus on Innovation in IT, taking courses such as Innovative Data Management, Cybersecurity, Internet of Things and Web Development, Advanced Topics in Artificial Intelligence, Sustainable Information Systems, User Interface and User Experience, and Strategy and Innovation. They will also take a Foreign Language and Research Workshop 3. In the fourth semester, students will complete a 5-month internship in a company and then take the final examination, which is worth 20 ECTS.

The application process varies depending on your region. If you are from Campus France countries, please send the bot 'Campus France'. If you are from Europe, send 'Europe'. utterances: can you tell me about campus france?
answers: International students from Campus France countries: apply in the local Campus France office and using the platform Etudes En France <https://pastel.diplomatie.gouv.fr/etudesenfrance/dyn/public/authentification/login.html?codeLangue=EN>. All information on the webpage of the international relation office of the university. <https://www.ut-capitole.fr/preparing-your-arrival/procedures-d-admission/hors-programmes/titulaires-de-diplomes-etrangers-candidats-en-l3-m1-377644.kjsp?RH=1347958954523>

For international students from Campus France countries, the application process varies depending on your region. If you are from Campus France countries, you should apply at the local Campus France office and use the Etudes En France platform. The university's international relations office webpage contains all the relevant information and procedures for admission. You can find detailed instructions and guidelines on the following links:

Etudes En France Platform: Etudes En France
University International Relations Office: International Relations Office
These resources will provide you with the necessary information and steps to follow when applying for admission.
International students from EU or non-Campus France countries: Applications are usually open in March-April on the university portal which will be linked here. Interview and response in April-May.

utterances: what about those who live in france
answers: French students, or international students holding a French Bachelor degree: Applications open in April-May. Interviews and response in June.

For French students and international students with a French Bachelor's degree, the application period typically begins in April-May. During this time, applicants can submit their applications. The university conducts interviews and provides responses to the applicants in June.
Usually the program starts in September, send 'application' to know how to apply to the program.
Typically, the program commences in September. If you would like to learn more about the application process for the program, please send the keyword 'application'.
